text.text: A Guide to London Fields

Once upon a time, not so long ago, people wouldn't dare to even cross big bad London Fields unless travelling in a mob. But times have gone and changed and now it seems like people never actually leave London Fields. In artisan bakeries beneath railway arches, upscale bars on rooftops and cosy pubs on street corners you'll find plenty of well-dressed types on the freelancer hustle: mooching, chatting and generally looking like they know what they're doing with their lives. 

This green nook of Hackney has, as the mad swarm of Broadway Market shows, become a real destination and there are several reasons for that. Here are some of them:
Best for... grabbing your weekend loaf

tip.text:
If we were the suspicious sorts, we'd begin to suspect there was something a little fishy about E5 and their growing bakery empire. How did they expand so quick? Is that flour really flour? Are they planning on a bread monopoly? But let's put those concerns to one side and enjoy this institution for what it is: a purveyor of delicious organic and natural sourdough bread.

In one arch you'll find the cafe, a busy hub where affluent Hackneyites come in for their routine cup of joe, fresh lunches and cakes and treats. In another arch, you've got their store, which is all about artisan goods at appropriately inflated prices. And then the mill itself, where all that...milling takes place and the dough transforms into truly delicious bread. Look out for their bread and pizza making classes too, which are super popular.

text.text:
E5's burgeoning bread empire now fills three arches and supplies most of the cafes in Hackney. It's enough to have us suspecting it might be some kind of Soprano-waste-management-esque front, but what a delicious front it is. 

What they do here centres around organic and natural sourdough bread and all bread-y related offshoots: from artisan cakes to wholesome breakfasts and lunches. It's often pretty busy, with affluent Hackneyites stopping by to get their weekend fix or parking themselves out front and getting their gossip on. There's all sorts to talk about in these parts.
Best for... a friendly fix

tip.text:
Climpson & Sons began as but a humble street stall trading on the market; they now shift their magic beans to places as far flung as Rome, Prague and Deptford. This is its flagship cafe: a buzzing, super friendly place that regulars slope sleepily into morning after morning to get what they need to see them through.

Just like Jack and his giant plant, the hype all stems from the bean, so that’s what must be sampled here through a delicate, velvety latte or flat white. Their outdoor pews are prime real estate, but do be careful on Saturdays when you'll have to clamber over man, woman and child to get your coffee - is it worth the hassle? Probably.

text.text:
From humble street stall to coffee mecca, Climpson & his many sons now send their beans to as far flung destinations as Prague, Rome and Deptford. Here we have their flagship cafe: a buzzing, super friendly pitstop for sleepy regulars who slope in morning after morning to get what they need to see them through.

Their outdoor pews are prime real estate, particularly so during the Saturday surge when every person in London Fields seems in desperate need of a latte.
Best for... community kickbacks

tip.text:
Run by the super friendly Diddy herself, this is an all-day cafe/bar that's quickly become a local hub - the kind of place where you'll overhear a convo going on next to you and feel compelled to join in. They're not trying to do anything too fancy here, just provide a colourful, chilled spot to unwind, chat and feel at home, and we're big fans.

A short menu offers staple brunch bits, and if you’re after something stronger, there’s a reasonably priced cocktail list to check too (£5.50 Aperol spritzes... for real). London is short on continental-style places to get cocktails late without the formalities of a bar; this is just that laid-back ticket.

text.text: The community vibes are strong at this place, and we couldn't be more in favour of it. Diddy's (run by the super-friendly Diddy herself) is an all day cafe/bar that's quickly become a local favourite - the kind of place where you'll overhear a convo going on next to you and feel compelled to join in. They're not trying to do anything too fancy here, simply provide a colourful, chilled spot to unwind, chat and feel at home. And we're big fans.
Best for... a trendy pint

tip.text:
Before passing the doors at Spurstowe Arms, take a quick look and make sure you’re wearing your Sunday best. Because the Hackneyites who typically frequent this one seem to generally be a) well-dressed and b) pretty damn attractive. If that doesn't deter, or you fancy yourself up to assimilating, you'll find a super cosy, aged tavern with plenty of vintage charm.

A one room joint dominated by a central bar, you'll spot fresh flowers, candles, wonky lights, refurbished mirrors, vintage paintings and art deco posters. It's effortlessly cool, silently saying, 'Oh what, this thing? We just found it’. There are a few ales on tap but nothing out of the ordinary, and the food is pointed towards gastro, with bar food, sharing boards and a couple of mains changing each month.

What this is, though, is either the physical embodiment of a hangover cure or a venue for a group chill, where you can get together either in the walled - and often busy - beer garden out back, or on a candlelit corner table and enjoy a booze-aided commune.

text.text: Before passing the doors at Spurstowe Arms, take a quick look and make sure you’re wearing your Sunday best. For this is where the cool cats drink: a super cosy, aged tavern with plenty of vintage charm rife with fresh flowers, candles, wonky lights, refurbished mirrors, vintage paintings and art deco posters. It's effortlessly cool, silently saying, 'Oh what, this thing? We just found it’. A fine place to enjoy a booze-aided commune.
Best for... a dependable grill

tip.text:
We all need that dependable, cheap Middle Eastern joint 'round the corner: giving you a bit of nutritional support when times are tough and times are tiring. Anatolia Ockabasi is just that spot for all of that, beating off some very mixed competition on Mare Street with a nice selection of grilled meats, mezes and pides. A huge big charcoal grill dominates this place and it's a mesmerising sight to see it in action.

This is a no-frills kind of place and that's really how we like our kebabies. Kebabies? Have we just coined something weird and wonderful? Hmm. Our picks include the lamb kofte, the moussaka or the hot mixed meze but really, it's all pretty good. A sensible option if you fancy something tasty but don't want to spend big.

text.text: If we had our way (and one day we will), every area would have a cheap and dependable Middle Eastern joint, providing something tasty when times are tough or tiring. A long charcoal grill dominates this place and it's a mesmerising sight to see it in action, especially when a) feeling a little loose and b) the lamb kofta is on the receiving end of that heat. It's a no-frills kind of place and that's really how we like our kebabbies.
Best for... sumptuous eating

tip.text:
There's a few things we've come to expect from the P. Franco team: friendly staff, high-brow cooking and an eye-opening selection of natural wine (some delicious, some strange but all dutifully explained to novices). So when we heard they were opening a restaurant in London Fields, we knew it would be a corker. As its name suggests Bright is well lit, airy, filled with plants, graphic posters and low-key furniture. A pretty chill backdrop for some sumptuous food.

We were won over by the simple flavours of al dente asparagus steamed in all sorts of fresh herbs and drizzled with lemon verbena oil; and some more surprising concoctions like a cold almond soup topped with crab meat and olive oil; or the soft, crispy pleasures of a Japanese katsu sando sandwich in white bread. Unlike a lot of the small plate restos of East London, portions don't leave you feeling hard done by (you won't find yourself dividing out the last broad bean or trying to share a prime number of tortellini). In fact our plate of pasta with sausage meat ragu was just the right size, thanks.

text.text: From the team behind P.Franco comes the kind of dining experience that you'll still be thinking about a couple of days later. In a (naturally) bright, airy and laid-back spot, this restaurant and wine bar does simple European dishes executed perfectly and, unlike a lot of the small plate restos of East London, portions don't leave you feeling hard done by. In fact our plate of pasta with sausage meat ragu was just the right size, thanks.
Best for... cosying up with a Belgian beer

tip.text:
Sitting in The Dove strangely reminds us of sitting below deck on a pirate ship. Maybe we've done that in a past life or something - it would certainly explain the scurvy. It's a dark and atmospheric tavern full of dark wood, candles and Hackney sorts sinking Belgian beers; a pub that's made for those winter nights that leave you scampering for cosiness and beer. Both are in abundance here with a huge selection of world beer, real ales and guest ales from micro craft-brewers.

The food here is also not just a passing thought. They have their own dining room which serves up an array of pub classics along with Thai specialities and that's without mentioning their Sunday Roast, known by those in the know to be one of the best you can find in this neck of the woods.

text.text: This is the kind of pub made for those winter nights that leave you scampering for cosiness and/or beer. It's a dark, atmospheric tavern full of dark wood, candles and mildly intoxicated sorts sipping on something rare from an impressive range of Belgian and real ales. Like being on a jovial pirate ship that's just pillaged Belgium's breweries. On nice nights, expect to see the action spilling haphazardly out onto the streets.
Best for... your go-to lunchtime sandwich

tip.text:
A Broadway Market hotspot, La Bouche is the kind of artisan, bougie deli and cafe that's busy whatever time of day you rock up there. It makes you wonder whether people ever actually leave London Fields for work. We reckon not. There are people looking busy on laptops, people chatting over cappuccinos and people sitting out on the prime real estate pavement tables, appearing impossibly cool & relaxed. And don't ever think you'll get a seat out there on a Sunday.

On its packed shelves you'll find all sorts of fancy speciality produce including cheese, veggies, meats, wines, pasta, biscuits and homemade cakes. The kind of food you'll acknowledge as looking delicious, but not quite delicious enough for you to spunk £7 on a packet of tortellini. Definitely check out the sandwiches here which are ideal for a cheap eat, coming in at around £5 and in a variety of breads - our tip is the duck rillettes with mustard.

text.text:
This is the kind of artisan, bougie deli that's busy whatever time of day you rock up there; we've done things you wouldn't imagine to get an outdoor table. Our tip is the £5 sandwiches, an ideal cheap eat especially when you scope out the duck rillettes with mustard variations.   

On the shelves you'll find all sorts of fancy speciality produce including cheeses, veggies, meats, wines, pasta, biscuits and homemade cakes. It's the kind of stuff you'll acknowledge as looking delicious, but not quite delicious enough to spunk £7 on a packet of tortellini.
Best for... a delicious Mediterranean mashup bistro

tip.text:
Do you sometimes wish you were Rick Stein on a culinary tour of the Mediterranean coast? Well you're not. But here's the next best thing: a charming bistro at the bottom of Broadway Market that seems to take all the best flavours from Spain, Italy, Greece and Turkey and compile them on one manageable, delicious menu.

It's an ambient spot, filled with overhanging greenery, gentle lighting and a soundtrack that occasionally drifts into Euro-pop. Like being on holiday somewhere sunny, but with nice food. Here are some things you absolutely must eat: the Picos blue and date croquetas; the octopus with hummus and cumin yoghurt; and the free range chicken thigh with honey poached apricots, sumac yoghurt and pistachios. And then end things with a deconstructed baklava with almonds, whipped cream and mango. 'Glorious' you say to yourself, as the camera pans out to reveal Regent's Canal.

text.text:
What happens when you combine all the best flavours from Spain, Italy, Greece and Turkey? Something pretty goddamn magical, it turns out. In an ambient spot right next to Regent's Canal, Tuyo is a tasty little tour of the Mediterranean via small plates. 

Some things you absolutely must eat include the oxtail croquetas; the octopus with hummus and cumin yoghurt; and the free range chicken thigh with honey-poached apricots. The flavours are incredibly dope and you'll soon feel that holiday surge flowing right through you - especially when you catch yourself shaking your nut to their euro-pop playlist.
Best for... an outdoor (heated) dip

tip.text: After what feels like a horrible eternity, London Fields lido is back up and running. This is the rarest of gems in London: a heated 50m outdoor pool with decent facilities to boot where inconceivably spritely speedo-clad swimmers glide up and down the lanes without losing their breath. They have swimming lessons for children and adults, a sunbathing area, cafe and swimfit sessions too. It gets super busy here in the summer and is probably best avoided on hot days.

text.text: Of course a trip to these parts wouldn't be complete/healthy without embarking on a dip in the lido, where inconceivably spritely speedo-clad swimmers glide up and down the lanes without losing their breath. It's a rare gem in London: a heated 50m outdoor pool with decent facilities to boot.
Best for... psychedelia-infused cocktails

tip.text:
Helgi’s is like being in the sixties - minus the racism and the sexism. A time warp in the middle of London Fields, transporting you back to the Summer of Luuuuvvvvvv. A better time, filled with free love, psychotropic drugs and hippie garms. A welcome break from the Tinder hook-ups, ket and bucket hats that plague our millennial generation.

The bar is intimate, and the smell of incense wafts in the air. A vinyl player blasts out tunes from the 60s, whilst wavy, psychedelic projections cover the walls. To properly enjoy the vibe, a cocktail is needed, of course. Try the Alabama Slammer, a mix of sloe gin, whisky, Galliano and Cointreau topped with orange juice. Some might say mixing that much alcohol is a bad idea, but this is the 60s honey, and mixing all substances is to be encouraged.

text.text:
Helgi's is a real time warp; a trip to the summer of love with all that hedonistic bonking, the psychotropic drugs and hippie garms. Which, when you think about it, isn't so far away from today's Tinder hook-ups, ket odysseys and bucket hats. The bar is mythical and moody, with the smell of incense wafting in the air, a vinyl player blasting out grooves from the 60s and wavy, psychedelic projections covering the walls. 

Get yourself an Alabama Slammer, a mix of sloe gin, whisky, Galliano and Cointreau topped with orange juice. Some might say mixing that much alcohol is a bad idea, but this is the 60s honey, and mixing all substances is to be encouraged.
Best for... cocktails at sunset

tip.text:
The well-loved pop-up Night Tales has taken the leap into brick and mortar to give you NT’s Bar. Make the trek up the several flights of stairs and be greeted to an impressive open plan space adorned with plants and all things millennial. With huge windows and a south-facing roof terrace, this makes for an ideal spot to watch the sunset over the city- cocktail in hand, of course.

Cocktails here are no nonsense - inventive but classy - with all cordials, infusions and shrubs made in house. You might be paying a little more for the view, location and oozin' cool but by George is it worth it.

text.text: Up another staircase is another relaxing cafe-cum-bar that feels like it's had plenty of dough injected into it. By day, Morty & Bob's is providing the grilled cheese sandwiches and salads; then evening draws in and those tales begin as the sinking sun bathes the south-facing terrace in a delightful faded glow. With a cocktail in hand, it'll cause all kinds of romantic notions, we promise. It's been known to pop off here on Friday and Saturday nights, though not all the way off - there's a 1.30am curfew, after all.
Best for... sweaty jazz sessions

tip.text:
The infamous eight-piece jazz band Kansas Smitty have had a permanent roof drawn over their jazzy sounds at this prohibition style bar. If you're not there for the jazz, be there for the juleps - gin paired with nettle, elderflower, coriander, apple pear and mint goes down a treat.

Throughout the week the venue comes alive as a live music hub for musicians to rehearse, perform and get their creative juices flowing. On Wednesdays the bar hosts the ‘Basement Tapes’, a weekly gig featuring new projects, guest performers, secret shows and new pieces written and rehearsed that week in the bar.

text.text:
If you like your bar's small, dark and sweaty with a large probability of live jazz music then you'll certainly be digging Kansas Smitty's. In a basement off Broadway Market this jiving lil' space regularly hosts super talented musicians doing it LIVE. Occasionally it can get a little bit too experimental but thems the risks of jazz, friend. 

A reliable date night spot if you want to appear suavely sophisticated, but don't actually plan on being able to hear what your date has to say for themselves.
Best for... a cheap eat

tip.text: On first inspection this seriously low-key spot feels like it might not have long left on this plot of uber hot Broadway Market retail space, but poke your head inside and you’ll find a strong contingent of dedicated followers. Maybe it’s because there is a gap in the market round here for no-frills cafe; maybe it’s the lack of any discernible pretension; or maybe it’s the cheap-as-chips gözleme, made fresh to order in the window and served steaming and flaky as hell (hell is probably flaky right?). Whatever it is, we like it. When the property developers inevitably rear their heads, we’ll be first on the picket line.

text.text: On first inspection this seriously low-key spot feels like it might not have long left on this plot of uber hot Broadway Market retail space, but poke your head inside and you’ll find a strong contingent of dedicated followers. Maybe it’s because there is a gap in the market round here for no-frills cafe; maybe it’s the lack of any discernible pretension; or maybe it’s the cheap-as-chips gözleme, made fresh to order in the window and served steaming and flaky as hell (hell is probably flaky right?). Whatever it is, we like it. When the property developers inevitably rear their heads, we’ll be first on the picket line.
